If this is fake, all Rosaline has to prove is that the kakao messages this person has  posted as proof to be doctored. She is not responding. Now that I've written it all out it seems like they could vring this to court. Hope they do, for truth's sake

text: @Kim Sylvia but it seemed like Rosaline already finished planning for A's entrance exam and just needed to teach her crash course style, yet the parents confronted Rosaline and wanted a refund. I did feel like she could have responded to A's messages better to resolve the situation (tho it would have been better also if A had chased her immediately after the situation to resolve it). Also, Rozaline didn't take to social media but instead, told a fan in DMs, a place where its private instead of releasing a statement. So idk what you mean when you say she took to social media.

I understand that preparing a dance takes time, but whatâ€™s the point of making the student pay for the choreography when the student was never given it. Itâ€™s like saying, oh Iâ€™m not going to give you this painting but you can pay me for doing the work. Like if sheâ€™s upset that she wasted her time making the dance for the student, then she shouldnâ€™t have delayed her dance practice for a whole 3 months. And I do agree that if Rozalina answered the student properly as a professional should do, then this wouldnâ€™t have even happen. But of course, we donâ€™t know if this ACTUALLY happened.

author: Valerie Ng
text: It's funny how international fans are defending Rozalin because she's friends with Chaeyeon? Where was that energy when Monika was hated on for her harsh but honest comments? As a Southeast Asian myself, I am ashamed to see such hypocritical comments from fellow Southeast Asians defending Rozalin when they have no basis to believe in her. You can still be a fan of Rozalin regardless of the verdict, but it is still too early to pass judgements before the legal process has run its due course. Thank you all once again for bringing shame to the region.

author: Ruko
text: @Kimberly Tran she never showed her work to the student because the parents cancelled before they even had their first session, how do you know there already hadn't been anything prepared? And its not that she wouldn't start, she physically couldn't because of her work schedule and when asking A, A understood and agreed to push back the practice sessions.  You ask whats the point of making the student pay for the choreography when the student was never given it? It's the same concept as going into Starbucks, paying for a coffee, your mom who's with you feels they are taking too long and demands for a refund. At that point, they might already be putting the lid onto the cup of coffee but your mom doesn't know, she just demands that refund. Was the coffee made? Possibly. Probably. But will she get that refund? No.  It's easy to see in a physical situation like this because physical transactions like that won't get you a refund unless something is wrong with the item you received. But in this case, its not something tangible, its a choreography.   For all you know, rozaline could have stayed up past her working hours just to choreograph for A's project. For this to be cancelled and to give a full refund means that everything she did was for nothing, and it wasn't even because A didn't want the choreography. The painting example can be a good example but you're not seeing everything that goes into that painting. Say you get commissioned to paint this large painting for 3k. They give the full payment etc so you go out, buy the canvas, but all the paints etc, spend hours on end sketching, painting. Then once you're done, client comes and scolds you, saying that you took too long, they want full refund.   That 3k could probably pay for your mortgage, bills, groceries for a month, but if you give a full refund now, you've just gone into a deficit. You would have paid out of your own pocket for the canvas, paints, and most importantly, your TIME. Time you could have used to earn money.  To me, I do acknowledge and agree that Rozaline could have handled this better. In fact, she could have offered to still teach A the choreography since she probably already had, but just in a more relaxed period, not for the admission project. Or even just sent a video of the choreography to the student and not teach her f2f. However, I do see it as Roazaline respecting her time and her work. She knows what she's worth even though she could have handled it better.

author: Kimberly Tran
text: @Ruko  I do agree with her understanding her worth, but Iâ€™m pretty sure the student just wanted some type of refund. The parents was probably going to take any type of refund that they could get. But you have to understand that SHE DELAYED the first practice for 3 months. Of course, she might be busy with new projects, but if you already put the student on your schedule already, you should also put her as a priority too. This is a high school student that we are talking about by the way. She has an exam and of course the parents would want to cancel if their student isnâ€™t getting the lessons that she deserved. The student was understanding for a good 3 months. Practicing for a dance exam takes sooooo much time and the fact that Rozalina wasnâ€™t taking it more serious than expected is the reason why many netizens are upset. Plus, the student specifically went to Rozalina for the admission project because she liked her dance style and wanted to do well on the exam. But, instead she got replies on â€œLets do it next timeâ€ for the past 3 months and almost had days where SHE didnâ€™t even reply. Thatâ€™s not fair. Of course the parents will cancel those lessons before the first one because the first one might not even happen. Iâ€™m pretty sure the parents were calling Rozalina to ask her WHEN is the first lesson is happening, not to REFUND their money or to cancel it. Iâ€™m glad that her exam was canceled because Iâ€™m pretty sure she wasnâ€™t going to have enough practice in time to find a new, reliable teacher. And as always, we donâ€™t know if this situation even happened.

author: dear yuuki
text: @s2 Yeongji just translating "Before judging Rosalind as we want, I admit that we have to listen to Rosalind, not just the victim's claim. However, this revelation should be viewed differently from the previous revelations (school violence, etc.).  Victims who were unable to speak properly at the time of school violence due to class or bullying among students face the perpetrators who are exposed as clean images on TV or media after they become famous. The painful memories of bullying and violence created by the words and actions of those pretentious people affect the lives of the current victims, so I want to see them as celebrities who live with false images and are loved by the public. Victims of school violence are exposing it.  If you look at the KakaoTalk evidence and student claims that Rosaline and the victim shared, it is very clear that the student could not have said such a thing at the time.  The reason the student tried to pass on Rosalind in a very respectful way until the very end, calling her a teacher and saying politely, is because the pie in the Korean women's dance version is not that big, and human connections are so important. As a well-known dancer, Rosalind receives the choreography for the entrance exam, and it doesn't matter if she doesn't.  However, if an entrance exam student who desperately needs dance practice instruction sues a dancer or something noisy happens because of it, gossip and rumors are nothing good in this small world for a student who is just dreaming of becoming a dancer and preparing for college. The fact is that both the girl student and Rosalind knew each other very well. This happened to a lot of students even before it came out on SWF, but after it aired and became more popular and influential, how much more could you use that power for such a bad thing? Even beyond simply rude words and actions and immoral deviance, this is an allegation of money-related fraud, including tax evasion.I saw in the comments that people in the dance industry said that such absurd things have happened often. At a time like this when the dance board is getting people's attention and growing pie lately, these absurd things need to be exposed and made known to the world so that the system can be fixed more transparently and fairly!"

author: froble
text: @Maria Saif The deposit is 2.9M right?  2.5 for the second class And 400,000 from the first class  Things happen then they confront Rozalin & agree with her offer 500,000 refund but they realize how low is it, so they reach out again but Rozalin insist that the refund is fair enough if you minus the Choreo fee + studio rental fee + professional fee.  Now, I don't like how Rozalin settle things but how would you call it a scam if she they agree with 500,000  Her actions could be considered as a work of a scammer but is it called scammer by the law?  Now the problem here is there's no contract of agreement that could help the student. She could use it to counter Rozalin arguments. In that contract, there should be a written statement that if the expectations doesn't meet the standards she could get a refund. That's a costumer's rights but what is the service's rights?   how much should be the refund? Even I thinks that 500,000 is low and If you look at it  2.9M -400,000 1st class -500,000 refund  2M=?? Studio rent + Professional Fee??  Professional Fee is a crucial topic because Rozalin could say her Professional fee cost 1.5M and that's acceptable.   As far as I know dancers are freelancers so they could set the rules just like how traditional & digital artist do commission  I think the points that should be look at are  1. Contract between the teacher & student 2. Costumer's rights & limits 3. Refund law 4. & Professional Fee  If full refund is impossible, the student could ask for a compensation fee for the damage which what happened. Rozalin just said that she talk with the parents & students and gave her a full refund. Done.  The problem is already is settled. Story ends.

author: Maria Saif
text: @froble you do realise you basically said she evaded taxes ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­   and yes they agreed on 500,000 won for 4 classes but she didnt even pay that for tons of months and THEN the student decided she wanted the full refund. like,,, 500,000 for four classes?? when did the price of one class drop from 400k to 100k? Please stop defending someone you dont know anything about. Rozalin only paid back the entire amount after the public found out about it so as to not ruin her reputation.

author: froble
text: @Maria Saif I'm not defending her, I would never made the joke above in the first place if I am trying to make her innocent.  Rozalin is a freelancer, & just like what I have said it's crucial. Cause she could adjust the time & payment & insist for the Professional fee  That's why if you read my reply to you,  I open the 2 different view of the teacher & students. I gave the perspective of the dancer so we could guess where shes coming from but I list & highlights the things that would help the student that's why I raise the question of having a "contract" so the student have a strong counter attack for Rozalin

author: Z
text: @Lady Pillow I heard she refunded the whole amount already. It was a misunderstanding between Rozalin and the students. The payment was apparently NON-REFUNDABLE to begin with (e.g. according to their terms and agreements) and due to busy schedules, Rozalin kept on rescheduling the date. However, Rozalin still refunded a certain percentage when they demanded it way before SWF. Of course the students felt like they got nothing from what they paid for, so somebody took advantage of the show to "expose" her.

author: Valerie Ng
text: â€‹@Z If you had a semblance of brains, you would infer that the non-refundable policy in most businesses apply in the event when the CUSTOMER cancels on them unfairly. FYI Customers have rights too and what Rozalin did was commit a criminal breach of trust by backing out without providing anything for her customer. In Korea, this is a justifiable case to be brought up to the small claims tribunal. I'm also curious, where did you read the T&C of their supposed "contract"? You're literally pulling things out of thin air. Yes, she refunded a small amount after much delay but she claimed that she prepared something for the student when the poor girl received no evidence of it? This was not a misunderstanding, even Rozalin admitted she was wrong and it's good that she has refunded the student. Don't give me that bullshit about your factual reporting when your tone implies that the student was unfair for taking advantage of the situation to "expose" her even though the student has exhausted all channels of communication to reach out to her. Go study some business law before you misconstrue facts.
